photo.description: The Pont Alexandre III is an arch bridge that spans the Seine, connecting the Champs-Élysées quarter and the Invalides and Eiffel Tower quarter, widely regarded as the most ornate, extravagant bridge in Paris. Four gilt-bronze statues of Fames watch over the bridge, supported on massive 17-meter socles, that provide stabilizing counterweight for the arch, without interfering with monumental views.

photo.title: Le pont Alexandre III

photo.tags: bridge france lamppost paris pontalexandreiii seine
photo.title: Reeds

photo.description: Pont Alexandre III spans across 107m of the River Seine, connecting pedestrian and auto traffic between Esplanade de Invalides in the 7th arrondissement and the Champs-Élysées quarter in the 8th arrondissement. The foundation stone was laid in 1896 by Tsar Nicholas II. His father, Tsar Alexander III, for whom the bridge is named after, reigned as Emperor of Russia from 1881 until his death in 1894 and established the Franco-Russian Alliance (or Dual Alliance) between the French Third Republic and the Russian Empire, ending the diplomatic isolation of France and undermined the supremacy of the German Empire. Construction began the following year, in 1897, under the engineers Résal and Alby, and the bridge was inaugurated with the nearby Petit Palais and Grand Palais in 1900 for the Universal Exhibition (World's Fair). The construction is a marvel of 19th century engineering, consisting of a single 6-meter high, 40-meter wide leaf arch with three joints, four cast steel girders and two masonry viaducts, that spans the Seine in a great curve, lowered just enough to not obstruct the view. Pont Alexandre III is the most ornate of the many river crossings in Paris, adorned with Art Nouveau lamps, cherubs, nymphs and wings horses. A crowd of sculptors contributed to the decoration. Four gilt-bronze equestrian statue groups supported on massive 17-meter socle providing stabilizing counterweight, watch over the bridge. Each socles is crowned by a Fame restraining Pegasus. On the Right Bank, the La Renommée de l'Agriculture (Fame of the Agriculture) by Gustave Michel, and La Renommée des Arts (Fame of the Arts) by Emmanuel Frémiet with, at their base, La France pacifique (Peaceful France), by Gustave Michel and La France de Charlemagne (Charlemagne's France) by Alfred Lenoir. On the Left Bank, La Renommée au combat (Fame of Battle) by Pierre Granet and La Renommée de la Guerre (Fame of War) by Clément Steiner with, at their base, La France de la Renaissance (Rebirth of France) by Jules-Félix Coutan and La France de Louis XIV (Louis XIV's France) by Laurent Honoré Marqueste. At each end of the balustrade is a sculptural group, Lion à l'enfant by Georges Gardet. The keystones are decorated with two compositions in hammered copper representing, upstream, the Nymphes de la Seine (the Seine Nymphs) bearing the arms of Paris, and, downstream, the Nymphes de la Néva (Nymphs of the Neva) bearing the arms of Russia by Georges Récipon. On the bridge parapet, at the foot of the pillars, are four groups of water spirits with fish and seashells sculpted in beaten copper: On Left Bank, upstream is Néréide, and downstream Enfant au poisson (Child with Fish) both by André Massoule; On the Right Bank, upstream is Enfant au crabe (Child with Crab) and downstream is Fillette à la coquille both by Léopold Morice. Four monumental candelabra by Henri Désiré Gauquié are surrounded by cupids and sea monsters.

photo.title: Pont Alexandre III

photo.description: Small statue of a cherub on the Pont Alexandre III with Eiffel Tower in background in Paris. This cherub is of one of the many statues lining the Pont Alexandre III bridge which spans the Seine River in Paris. The bridge was built between 1896 and 1900 and is known for its Art Nouveau lamps, cherubs, Nymphs and golden Pegasus horses. Tsar Alexander III of Russia laid the foundation stone in October 1896. This bridge was inaugurated, like many other structures nearby, in 1900 for the World’s Fair.
photo.tags: alexandre alexandreiii angel architecture art beautiful beauty blue bridge built capital city cityscape construction culture detail avenuedeschampselysees eiffel europe exterior famous france french historical history journey landmark metal metropolis modern monument old paris parisdetails parisiandetails place pont river sculpture seine sky statue structure tourism tourist tower travel urban vacation vintage leurope frankreich europa fransa avrupa d90 nikon nikond90 nikondigital nikondslr
photo.title: Parisian Details

photo.description: Camera + Lens : GF1 + VOIGTLÄNDER NOKTON CLASSIC S.C 35mm F1.4 Pont Alexandre III / Ave Winston Churchill, Paris Looking onto Grand Palais and Petit Palais Not sure why the barriers/railings were there - perhaps to protect people from bumping into those dangerous lamp-posts. Pont Alexandre III is an arch bridge that spans the Seine, connecting the Champs-Élysées quarter and the Invalides and Eiffel Tower quarter, widely regarded as the most ornate, extravagant bridge in Paris. The bridge, with its exuberant Art Nouveau lamps, cherubs, nymphs and winged horses at either end, was built between 1896 and 1900. It is named after Tsar Alexander III, who had concluded the Franco-Russian Alliance in 1892. His son Nicholas II laid the foundation stone in October 1896. The style of the bridge reflects that of the Grand Palais, to which it leads on the right bank. The construction of the bridge is a marvel of 19th century engineering, consisting of a six-metre high single span steel arch. The design, by the architects Joseph Cassien-Bernard and Gaston Cousin, was subject to strict controls that prevented the bridge from obscuring the view of the Champs-Élysées or the Invalides. -/- from Wikipedia

photo.description: Limited Internet access on my devices in Paris, so this is the first chance I've had to upload them. I've said it before, but I love running through a new city. It's such an awesome way to see the place, and morning or evening light makes for some dramatic views. These pictures were of the Eiffel Tower but the Arc de Triomphe and the other landmarks I passes were also beautiful in the early am sun.
